Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the impact of not buying sugary drinks on the grocery bill, suggesting that it won't go up at all.
Understate: The claim may be understating the possibility that grocery bills could increase even if consumers stop buying soda.
Lack enough support: The claim does not provide sufficient evidence or support to prove that not buying sugary drinks will have no impact on the grocery bill.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the only factor affecting grocery bills is the purchase of sugary drinks, ignoring other potential factors.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert suggests that the prices of other items similar to sugary drinks could increase due to the soda tax, indicating an alternative explanation for potential increases in grocery bills.
